The idea that meat and fat are nourishing is as old as meat and fat. We have been omnivores since before we were even human. Dr. Hu has never found a correlation without assuming that it was the same as causation, and he ignores the numerous recent meta-analyses which have found no connection between sat fat or meat consumption and chronic diseases.

Smoking is a straw-man argument. Lung cancer was rare before smoking, and the increased risk from smoking is 15-20x not smoking, and we are able to clearly rule out other factors. The supposed increased risk of any diseases from red meat consumption is less than 2x, and there are literally dozens of confounding factors. Same for eating whole grains -- nutritionally inessential, the supposed benefits are small, and there are dozens of confounding factors.

Good quality meats, fish, eggs, and dairy _are_ whole real foods, nutrient dense and satiating to the appetite. Most people _improve_ health when they eat more naturally fatty foods, and this has been demonstrated with numerous controlled trials with human subjects.

In another nightmarish year, 1968, there was no sunnier politician than Hubert Humphrey, the presidential nominee who was trying to make it three terms in a row for the Democrats with his "politics of joy." But that didn't jibe especially well with what Americans were experiencing in their daily lives.

As it turned out, the highly disreputable Richard Nixon, in a three-way race, gained 43.4 percent of popular vote and 301 in the Electoral College, and if George Wallace's totals are added to the rejection-of-the-status-quo demographic, the figures were 56.9 percent and 347. So, if nothing else, an angry, volatile electorate is unpredictable, even after having initially bought into Hope and Change or a historical equivalent, the New Frontier.

So given that Mrs. Clinton's poll numbers for honesty and trustworthiness are so deeply underwater -- with two-thirds of likely voters saying she is neither -- her newfound smiley face could be a much tougher sell for a potential Clinton 45 than the Democratic stage managers think. All the more so since so many working (or formerly working) people are still riddled with shrapnel from the economic time bombs set by Clinton 42.

Credibility is the coin of the realm, and Mrs. Clinton's best selling point is who she's running against. The key would seem to be overcoming, at long last, her problem with authenticity. As in pulling off what was best defined by, among others, George Burns: "Sincerity -- if you can fake that, you've got it made."

Thanks.  I agree that ULTRACOOL is a genuine word used in cosmology.  But it's not "a common word", so even if I got it I wouldn't count it towards my tally---my own goal (and others' may differ) is to find common words, having the puzzle maker's guarantee that there are enough of them to add up to the goal tally. COLORATURA is a little iffy that way too, but not nearly as much.  As it happens, I didn't need those three points either, so I didn't fret about whether it was fair game.

Ok, I defer to the cosmological definition of ultracool, just not to the Brooklyn-hipster hyphenated version with which I was familiar! For a fourth 3-pointer I had a slim hope - paper thin, really - that one who acculturates might be an acculturator but...nuh-uh. Foreign words are always tricky, I think acceptance as an answer depends on how widespread the usage, and even that can be questionable. Rucola (Italian for "arugula") didn't make the cut in the Times' answer key and I'm ok with that. In earlier Bees, rigatoni, cannelloni, and celli (plural of cello) did make the cut, and I agree with that. Similarly, coloratura describes some of the most famous sopranos of all time...Beverly Sills, Kathleen Battle, Maria Callas, Joan Sutherland, et. al., and one need not be a classical music buff to have had reasonable opportunity to encounter that word...although I did take special pleasure when I found it in the Bee.

@J. Grant: Do you realize that Ticketmaster makes $$ from fees they charge for selling you a ticket, and then (if you choose to re-sell through them, as scalpers often do) Ticketmaster charges the BUYER of the re-sold ticket fees in the range of 18% in addition to the cost of the actual ticket?

So if someone bought a ticket originally paying, for example, $179 and then re-sold it through Ticketmaster for $800 (not unusual in the case of Hamilton), Ticketmaster got fees on the original $179 ticket PLUS 18% of the $800 ticket.

So what incentive does Ticketmaster have to stop scalpers and their bots? Not much, IMO.

I think that Mr. Bruni missed an important message in the DNC convention: "together WE can." The world is not good. While America is one of the best positioned countries, we are challenged by shaky economies everywhere and dangerous geopolitical flash points all over the world. At home, while many states and most cities are doing well, there are pockets of deep depression fueling the rise of Trump. Restoring economic justice and personal dignity through new employment opportunities will help in the long run. Solving all these problems are formidable challenges. Mrs. Clinton and her team will not be able to tackle all these from Washington. The convention is a call for action and a call for sacrifice for ordinary citizens. For too long, our politicians ask too little of us. Only by doing more and doing better for your community and country, that we can tackle this challenge together. The optimism in the DNC convention comes from the faith that ordinary people will step up and help build a better world. I will put my faith in the American people over Trump any day and I hope many others will see the same optimism.
